item.title: Nicole Rust
item.description:
Why a (reductionist) statement from a popular undergrad neuroscience textbook is misleading
"In neuroscience, there is no need to separate mind from brain; once we fully understand the individual and concerted actions of brain cells, we will understand our mental abilities."
Bear, Mark; Connors, Barry; Paradiso, Michael A.. Neuroscience: Exploring the Brain, Enhanced Edition (p. 24).
The problem with this statement is that "more is different".
https://cse-robotics.engr.tamu.edu/dshell/cs689/papers/anderson72more_is_different.pdfIn that classic paper, Anderson explains why, in broad strokes, all of science doesn't just boil down to physics if elementary physical laws govern all happenings in the universe. The answer is that "the ability to reduce everything to simple fundamental laws does not imply the ability to start from those laws and reconstruct the universe." This is because new properties emerge from collective behavior of the parts. Because of it, we need chemists, biologists, psychologists and sociologists (not just physicists).In principle, one could infer the collective behavior of a system by exhaustively studying its parts and all their interactions; this is indeed where emergent properties come from (they are not mystical). In practice, this is not how science works; rather, when studying a complex system, one begins with the phenomenon that needs to be explained and then investigates its mechanism. For instance, if you want to understand the collective behavior of birds flying, you begin with an understanding that they flock (and some description of it); you don't begin by studying the rules that govern the flying decisions of one bird and then two and then three and the build a model of collective behavior that suggests flocking (and then, for the first time, take a peek). The problem with the Bear et al statement is that it implies that the order of operations is to exhaustively investigate the brain alone before taking a peek at the mind/behavior. It's precisely the fallacy that Anderson wrote about in 1972. (Note: I suspect the authors don't really believe it and it's just badly worded; I suspect that what they intended to argue against was a non-material soul that causally influences behavior; but I don't know.)

item.title: Luiz Pessoa
item.description:
Is mental activity just neural activity?
Imo an interesting counter is in terms of a reductio argument. Once we understand the action of brain cells we have to dig further down to understand the action of subcellular mechanisms, otherwise we don't really understand brain cells. But once we understand subcellular we need to understand how such molecular mechanisms come about, otherwise it's not real understanding. But molecules are huge, complex, dynamic and need to be understood in terms of...
Therefore, all explanations must be at the "quantum foam" level, otherwise we don't have real understanding. But since this absurd, we have a contradiction.@NicoleCRust
#neuroscience

item.title: Thomas Deffieux
item.description:
Glad to have our first paper out in the new journal Imaging Neuroscience !
Using a multiarray approach for highly sensitive functional ultrasound imaging of mouse brain functional networks !
https://direct.mit.edu/imag/article/doi/10.1162/imag_a_00030/117893/High-sensitivity-mapping-of-brain-wide-functional

item.title: Earl K. Miller
item.description:
New paper!
Under anesthesia, sensory signals get to the cortex but don't make it much farther.
Propofol-mediated Unconsciousness Disrupts Progression of Sensory Signals through the Cortical Hierarchy
https://doi.org/10.1162/jocn_a_02081
#neuroscience

item.title: Saman Abbaspoor
item.description:
If you're at #SfN23, swing by my poster on Nov 12th, from 8 to 12 pm. I'll be sharing our latest findings on hippocampal laminar recordings, superficial and deep pyramidal cells, their interactions with different inhibitory cell types, and their assembly organization in freely-behaving macaques. #SfN23 #poster links:
Website: https://tinyurl.com/5c7wjxx2
App: https://tinyurl.com/3d2mjz6f
@karihoffman @sfntweets
